threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: I work on a cruise ship AMA
threads.com:
See title, starting with a few FAQs

>how long and what do you do?
I started working on ships right out of university and ive made it my career, currently trying to get up to Cruise Director.

>where are you right now
Currently on a contract in the Caribbean, sailing out of Florida. About as entry-level as it gets.

>what’s the best cruise line for my vacation
If you have kids, Disney or Royal Caribbean. I can’t see reason to buy a cruise otherwise, it’s not a good travel method with the exception of a couple parts of the world (Alaska, Norway).

>can/do you sleep with the guests?
It’s prohibited and not worth it, there are plenty of female crew members who are down to fool around. I do have some adventurous friends though who partake. The bigger the ship the harder it is for them to catch you.

>I have no education/ambition, can I get a job on a ship?
Sure you can, but most likely you will work 8-10 hours a day every day for 6-8 months on a salary that cannot keep up with the western world’s cost of living,

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2359164
I’m musical director, which depending on the cruise line is an privileged or underprivileged position. MD is usually given the privileges of a 2 stripe or 2.5 stripe officer and is in charge of anywhere between 5 and 40 musicians (correlating with ship size)

In the case of your friend I have to say that f&b always gets the short end of the stick. They get the most roommates, and have both hardest and slowest promotional ladder to climb.

I’ll be transitioning to Assistant Cruise Director next year, it’s a better salary and one step closer to where I can comfortably work long term on ships.

>>2359254
Solo guitarist and solo pianist have a really nice deal, and on some companies get a better deal than Musical Director. It’s always a solo cabin, and some companies require them to have a day off a week. The cons - you’re gonna be the entertainment anchor of the musicians department, averaging 3 to 4 sets a night (minus the day off). Even the party band can be replaced by a DJ but for guests go nuts for going to the pub or piano bar and listening to a 1 man band churning out their favourites.

I’m not a solo musician but I would say the better gigs on the mainstream lines would be princess or Norwegian. I’m assuming you’re under 40.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

>>2356317
The actual answer:

AMERICA, as in US Customs and Border Patrol agents at an airport or land entry, do not check

For air travel, it is the responsibility of the airline to verify your status. Typically the only person who will do this is the check in agent when you check bags/get boarding pass. Whether or not they still check *at all* seems to be highly dependent on departure country/city and airline. Many report that airlines from certain countries, for instance Mexico Gemany and Singapore from what Ive seen, no longer check.

Even if they *do* check, they are advised by official DHS and CDC guidance to accept nonverifiable physical and digital proof, ie, literally anything including screenshots of a vaxpass so long as it has your name and birthday on it

Again, if you pass the airline check, you wont ever be asked again

Also word on the ground at Mexico land border crossings is that CBP, without airlines to pass responsibility to, have just refused to enforce the order and don't check at all. Worst case scenario you get turned away if they do check

Per the letter of the rule, you do not have to be vaccinated to enter the US. You have to carry verifiable OR NONVERIFIABLE physical or digital proof of vaccination, which CBP will not check, and the airline only maybe will check.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2357945
>amex plat is $695 now
OUCH, wasn't aware since I don't have a platinum card but when it was 10x points, it technically was the best as other cards just did not come close pointswise. I'm a believer in the Chase Sapphire since it's a great card overall and costs a fraction of what AMEX Plat will cost you (to the point where the extra $600 saved annually can just be put straight into a trip).
I hadn't heard of the Venture X, it looks really fucking good but for my personal uses it's kind of worthless. I tend to avoid big brand hotels and stay at cheap airbnb's that are close to where I want to be so those 10x points are mostly lost on me. The $300 annual credit for a flight is insanely good but if I poormax and don't travel one year, that cash is wasted and the 5x for flights stays the same. Lounge access is good but I never really use them (even back when I had an amex plat) because I tend to not spend time at airports or am comfy enough just chatting people up at the bar, better to pass out on my next flight instead of at a comfy chair in a lounge.
>>2358069
Don't do this. A significant factor in your credit score is number of applications for cards sent out and concurrent years as a member which means cancelling an account will impact your overall credit and can hurt you financially in the future when you cancel. The best thing to do is to downgrade a card of a specific company to save up on annual fees, so if you want to stop paying $695 on an amex platinum, you downgrade to their shittiest card and save about $600 a year. Outright cancellation will hurt if you don't keep at least something open with the CC company you signed up with and got the points from.

OP hasn't ever had a CC so he has no credit, no way he will be able to get a decent travel card like the Venture X, AMEX plat or Chase Sapphire. His best bet would be to do the Chase Freedom Ultimate/Flex and eventually apply for the sapphire, or a capital one credit builder and go for Venture X

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Any places I should definitely stop by?
I’m planning on going from Miami to Seattle and back to Miami
I have a whole month to kill
1st of January til 1st of February
What routes should I take?
Need help planning it out.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2356741
If you drove the straightest route with no deviation, you'd be looking at a gas bill of at least $1500. And 75 percent of your trip would be just empty highway driving with nothing to see. Ive driven across country on 6 different routes. There are better options, especially in the winter.

Here is what I would do. Fly in and out of Las Vegas, Salt Lake City, LA or San Fran. Do a West Coast loop. All the best shit is on the West Coast. You might get lucky and catch a good stretch of weather in southern California that time of year too. Definitely plan time to snowboard or ski in Lake Tahoe or Salt Lake. Spend at least 3 nights in Yosemite National Park. Don't spend all your time driving. Add time in between to stop and do shit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2356741
Go through the central part of the country or south. (or make a big circle)

Nashville is super cool, Memphis is kinda interesting, skip Beale Street, Skip St Louis and KC. Colorado is great, even i70 is a cool drive. While in Colorado, visit a box canyon town and a hotspring if you can get to one. Moab is right off i70 too, check that out. Four corners is a meme and too many indians. Cut straight on up to Portland from around SLC and visit Multnomah Falls. There's also bagby hotsprings out there if it's not snowed in... Levanworth WA is worth visiting if you want to trip east of the cascades out of Seattle. Consider taking the Anacortez Ferry to Orcas Island and driving to the summit of Mt Constitution (on a clear day you can see BC, Seattle, and Ranier). If you like snow sports, visit Mt Baker.

On the 2nd route, drive out to the Oregon/Wa coastline and take it all the way down to San Francisco. If you wind up on i5, CONSIDER crossing to crater lake (it's a meme imo) and take hwy97 down to Weed CA, it's a nicer drive if you aren't on the coast. Enjoy SF tourist stuff if you've never been. Cross the cascades into Owens Valley and visit those little towns and the drive around. Mammoth/Tahoe is on the way if you wanted to ski more, or visit the Donner party breakdown site near Truckee. Winnemuca is kinda neat, as is the drive down HWY 95, but that's for another Time. Cross over to Vegas and stop at the Hoover Dam. There's a super cool hot spring down the bottom of the ravine at the base of the dam. If you wind up near LA, do your touristy shit (mega meme) and drive over to take the Palm Springs Tram to the top of Mt San Jacinto. Idlewilde is a cool little town. Take i40 to the Grand Canyon. Eat at Blakes Lotta Burger chains in New Mexico. Stop in New Orleans on the way home.

>>2359019
there's already another thread for this in which the answer is given. tldr; you dont need to take it.

long answer:
AMERICA, as in US Customs and Border Patrol agents at an airport or land entry, do not check

For air travel, it is the responsibility of the airline to verify your status. Typically the only person who will do this is the check in agent when you check bags/get boarding pass. Whether or not they still check *at all* seems to be highly dependent on departure country/city and airline. Many report that airlines from certain countries, for instance Mexico Gemany and Singapore from what Ive seen, no longer check.

Even if they *do* check, they are advised by official DHS and CDC guidance to accept nonverifiable physical and digital proof, ie, literally anything including screenshots of a vaxpass so long as it has your name and birthday on it

Again, if you pass the airline check, you wont ever be asked again

Also word on the ground at Mexico land border crossings is that CBP, without airlines to pass responsibility to, have just refused to enforce the order and don't check at all. Worst case scenario you get turned away if they do check

Per the letter of the rule, you do not have to be vaccinated to enter the US. You have to carry verifiable OR NONVERIFIABLE physical or digital proof of vaccination, which CBP will not check, and the airline only maybe will check.

My 2 cent as tourist. I was in Gran Canaria two years ago, its good for a week but nothing more.

The west part of the island is full of lot of expensive holidays resorts. Lomo Quiebre is the best and only good part in this area, anything else like Los Caserones is just empty villages.

On the South part of the Island. We spend the most time in Maspalomas which was yeah shit. West side of the Town is just a bunch of holidays resorts and shopping mall. The East part is literally Mallorca 2.0. A lot of trash comes here to party with dirt cheap restaurants and clubs. If you enjoy the screaming of drunk british tourist at 3am and groups of teenangers while being harass by Turks trying to sell you club tickets, go for it. Also they was a Gay Parade in this Town a few years ago, is still full of faggotry.

East is just empty rocks, airport and locals. Has a nice restaurant (Faro de Punta) but nothing really for tourist.

Kinda sadly skip the North because I was sick but if you like outdoor it should be ok if you have a car. The Interior of the Island is yeah, closed restaurants, ghost villages if you enjoy that, a lot of heat and rocks.

Las Palmas de Gran Canaria wasn't good either. Everything is wear down, old kinda 2010 greece atmosphere. Just zoom in with Google Maps and imagine piss smell. A few churches to visist but nothing more.

Gran Canaria got economie wise fucked in the last decade. You better off with Island hopping out of season with a rent car. Meanwhile I have from Lanzarote and Fuerteventura only good memories but I was a child so Idk. Seems to be a better choice

Yeah, you gotta declare it. They'll give you a little card to fill out on the plane on the way back. You write down what you bought, and how much it costs. Then you pay a tax once you go through customs on the way back.

You get an allowance per person, and the taxes/duty isn't that much. I wouldn't be too worried, the customs mutts aren't that annoying if you're friendly. If you have all your receipts in your hand along with your passport and you act kinda cute/inquisitive like how a kid would about it and say things like "I bought some clothes and stuff in Europe, but I don't know the taxes work, here's my receipts" they might just wave you in.

>>2358373
>heading to london for about 6 months in january, since it’s no longer part of the EU, can i leave to go elsewhere like germany for example for 3 years, and then reset the time limits?
I’m actually not sure what the current terms are for the UK (depends on where you’re coming from, of course), but this works going the opposite direction—when you run out of the 90 continuous days you’re allowed to spend in the Schengen Area in mainland Europe (most of the EU except for its Easternmost members, plus Iceland, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, and Norway), you can spend 90 days in either the UK or a non-Schengen country in Eastern Europe to reset the clock.

>I don’t remember correctly but i think it was something like 180 days in schenzen countries ?
Most people get 90 days out of every 180, so a total of 180 days in any given year but with two 90 day gaps. In for three months, then out (in the UK, non-EU Eastern Europe, or non-Schengen EU Europe [Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia, or Cyprus]) for three months.

>Shenzhen
Such an insult to the glorious metropolis of Schengen, Luxembourg, that gave its name to the treaty unifying customs and border controls across twenty-six nations… pic related.

last_replies.com:
I did a baltics trip in September. Vilnius 4 days, Riga 2 days, Tallin 4 days with day trips to Narva and Helsinki.

Vilnius - Modern, clean/safe and nice architecture. However, approaching western euro prices and on the whole somewhat boring. The best thing I did and would recommend is a soviet history walking tour, I also met an American on the tour and went out drinking later on in the evening. People were not overly friendly and the girls are quite standoffish and reserved (this is a common theme for the whole of the Baltics).

Riga - My personal view on this place is it's not worth coming here, although I encourage you to discover your own opinion on the place. On the whole I found it by far the least clean and safe of the three capitals, unwelcoming and above all boring with a lack of anything really unique and interesting to see. The main pros are the market is cool to spend some time exploring and it is the most affordable.

Tallin - is by far the most interesting of the three. The old town is cool to walk around, public transport is very good, interesting museums and Everyone speaks English. It isn't as great as many expats would have you believe and it is no longer a budget destination either. People are in general, reserved, cold and not open to friendly interaction. However, I got to know a local and it became a way better experience and the longer I stayed the more I enjoyed it.

threads.com:
so /trv, I have about £20,000 to my name and if I'm leaving the country can sell my car which is another £6000 or so. Given this, am I best to spend 6 months in Mexico or Thailand? Mexico interests me more but I am concerned about the extremely high crime rate in some cities.

Anyone whos been to either please tell me about where to rent where to stay etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2356286
There's some valid considerations in this thread about safety in Mexico. Mexico can be a safe country, but the further you try to stretch your money, the less safe it will be. The same isn't true of Thailand. How much of your money do you want to spend?
Also consider visas. Depending on your nationality, you can probably stay in Mexico for 180 days as a tourist. In Thailand, you will need to do at least one visa run if you use 60 day tourist visas plus 30 day extensions, or two visa runs if you use tourist-exempt entries plus 30 day extensions.
Also consider languages. If you speak Spanish, Mexico becomes cheaper and more navigable. (You can probably learn a lot of Spanish during your stay there too, if you have the time and drive to learn it.) You don't need to learn more than a few polite words in Thai regardless of where and how you would live there.
Personally I would choose Thailand because I've had negative experiences in LatAm. But much of that is on me, I like to live and travel on a budget and meet interesting people and sleep with local women. In LatAm, that is just asking for trouble. If I was the type who goes to resorts or stays in nice hotels and doesn't go out at night, maybe my experiences in LatAm would have been different. On the other hand, my only real worry about safety in Thailand is the traffic and crazy drivers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2356880
Fuck my gf (ES)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Both are reasonable countries to visit. I've probably spent a year total in Mexico over business trips and I've visited Thailand on leisure. I think it all depends on your food and entertainment preferences, I really prefer Mexican cuisine its diversity and flavor profile but I prefer Thailand when it comes to nightlife and partying.

I'm biased because of my job - both countries feel comparatively safe, I've genuinely never been robbed or threatened in either country and I find that the CNN mentality of many Americans concerning safety in both countries is pretty laughable. I've been hassled more in Miami and Chicago than I have walking around Mexico City, even though I am visibly white and not a local. Shootings aren't as often as people make it out to be and the only cities I've ever heard gun shots were Denver and Johannesburg.

Latin women tend to be hotter, imo, but aren't nearly as easy as Thais, especially when it comes to the Mexicanas with more European ancestry. Also I noticed that money doesn't impress nearly the same in Mexico City - in a few neighborhoods, like Polanco and Santa Fe, the girls came from families with more money than I'll ever see in my life. In Bangkok being a middle-aged European with more than a few thousand in your bank account will be far more impressive and the girls seem to care less if you're fat or ugly.

I wish I could say to split your time and make your decision that way - a few weeks in Mexico visiting museums and restaurants in Mexico City, going to some of the smaller cities in Mexico, etc. and then going to Thailand for the rest of your time might be a great way to compare experiences.

My job involves security, btw, and I've never known directly of a foreigner getting kidnapped, despite the millions of dumb drunk tourists who visit a year. It's mostly cartel activity in the north. In Thailand you don't have to worry about getting shot as much as stabbed by a drunk Thai wanting your pocket change or the deadly traffic.

Went to Vlorë in southern Albania for a few days in late September, and now I feel like telling you about it!

Over all, it was a great trip. It was very affordable, the weather was amazing (at least by Swedish standards), the locals were incredibly friendly and helpful and despite not being the most touristy city in Albania, Vlorë had a fair amount of beautiful buildings and interesting monuments.

Young people speak alright English, but the older generation is better at Italian and hardly knows any English. Me and my friends have learned basic Spanish and French in school, which works fine for communicating with Italian speakers.

The total price of the trip, including flights, gasoline to get to the airport, airport parking, hostel, food and everything else came out to €134.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2357779
I think it’s only happened once so far, but Lufthansa did sue a passenger for €2000 for violating their terms and conditions. Tickets are a form of contract, so there is at least theoretically legal precedent from other areas of law.

It was a scare tactic, the case was thrown out, and in this particular guy’s case it was extremely obvious that he hadn’t missed a flight by accident but had engineered it deliberately as a skiplagged trip—I believe he booked a separate last leg of his trip via another Lufthansa flight.

But it illustrates how much airlines hate it. They’ll definitely kick you out of their FF programs and take all your miles/points away even if they don’t resort to symbolic legal grandstanding, and I’ve heard of airlines sending staff to yell at people about it (not sure if this accomplishes anything, but it sends a message).

last_replies.com:
>>2355150
>I'm an OT (makes prothesis and such), very niche job. It's a pain in the ass because different countries have different regulations (e.g. Switzerland splits my job in two different jobs, in US only doctors can make my job etc.)
Switzerland is especially fussy with professional licensing — I know a lot of people here with various fairly sophisticated technical qualifications from other parts of Europe (a Spanish optometrist, a Dutch pharmacist, a few different types of therapists) who have had a hard time getting their credentials transferred here without additional local technical training or education. I even know a German doctor who struggled to work here, and her medical license is actually automatically transferred, she just has to jump through bureaucratic hoops in order to be hired to practice locally (she ended up taking a job back over the border in small-town Germany instead).

Another challenge is that in your line of work the workplaces are likely to be all German-language (maybe French but most big medical and scientific work is in German speaking cantons), rather than English, which is in practice going to be mostly Swiss German.

But it’s worth getting some professional experience in your field, if it interests you at all, and then seeing about prospects. There might be specialist medical manufacturing/production opportunities with prospective transferability of skills. If you’re an EU citizen you can just come in and start applying for stuff, you might be surprised.
